name: Amazon
description: Amazon is the world's largest e-commerce platform offering millions of products across various categories. Users can browse and search for products, read customer reviews, compare prices, and add items to their shopping cart. The platform provides features like Prime membership for fast shipping, wish lists for saving items, order tracking, and easy returns. Customers can also manage their account settings, payment methods, addresses, and view their purchase history.
suitability_reasoning: Amazon’s core workflows are structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (products, inventory, carts, orders, addresses, payments, shipments, returns, reviews). Most user tasks can be supported with realistic fake catalog/pricing/shipping data and stateful order lifecycles. The main limitations are true relevance ranking, fraud/risk, real payment rails, and real logistics/warehouse integrations, which can be approximated but not replicated faithfully.
simulatable_features: User accounts (register/login), profiles, preferences
Address book management (add/update/delete shipping and billing addresses)
Payment method vaulting metadata (cards as tokens, gift card balances, stored payment preferences)
Product catalog browsing (categories, product detail pages, variations, attributes)
Inventory and seller offers (in-stock status, quantity, condition, seller rating)
Pricing and promotions (list price, sale price, coupons, promo codes) with deterministic rules
Search endpoints with simple filtering/sorting (category, price range, brand, rating) using synthesized indexes
Shopping cart CRUD (add/remove items, update quantity, save for later)
Wishlist CRUD (create lists, add/remove items, share tokens)
Checkout simulation (shipping options, tax calculation via fixed rules, order placement)
Order history and order detail retrieval
Order status lifecycle (placed, paid, packed, shipped, out_for_delivery, delivered, canceled)
Shipment tracking events as synthesized scans (timestamped location updates)
Returns/exchanges workflows (RMA creation, return labels metadata, refund status)
Refunds and store credit balances (ledger entries, refund methods)
Reviews/ratings CRUD (create review, edit, delete, vote helpful) with moderation flags
Customer service cases (contact support, ticket status, messages, resolution codes)
Prime membership subscription state (active/canceled, renewal dates, benefits flags)
non_simulatable_features: Real-world search relevance and ranking at Amazon scale (behavioral signals, personalization, A/B ranking models)
Authentic review authenticity/fraud detection and trust scoring
Real payment processing (authorization, chargebacks, 3DS, bank network interactions) beyond a mock gateway
Real-time logistics, carrier integrations, and true tracking numbers/scan feeds
Dynamic marketplace pricing driven by competitive intelligence and external seller repricing tools
Personalized recommendations/ads based on large-scale ML and user behavioral graphs
Content authenticity such as real product images/videos and rich brand media (can store metadata but not replicate true assets)
Regulatory/compliance and risk systems (tax nexus determination at full fidelity, sanctions, KYC/AML where applicable)

name: YouTube
description: YouTube is the leading video sharing and streaming platform with billions of videos. Users can watch content ranging from educational tutorials to entertainment, upload their own videos, and build channels. The platform supports subscribing to favorite creators, creating and managing playlists, commenting on videos, and engaging with the community through likes and shares. It also offers features like video quality settings, subtitles, and personalized recommendations based on viewing history.
suitability_reasoning: Many important YouTube workflows are structured and CRUD-friendly (channels, video metadata, subscriptions, playlists, comments, likes, moderation, basic analytics) and can be backed by fully synthesized SQLite data. However, YouTube’s core value is video hosting/streaming, encoding/transcoding, content delivery, and large-scale search/recommendation/ranking—features that depend on real media files, complex pipelines, and ML-driven personalization that cannot be meaningfully reproduced with simple synthesized REST APIs.
simulatable_features: User accounts/profiles (create/update), settings, and simple preferences
Channel creation and management (name, description, branding metadata)
Video object lifecycle using metadata only (upload request placeholder, title/description/tags/category, visibility, publish time, status)
Playlists CRUD (create playlists, add/remove/reorder items, privacy settings)
Subscriptions/following (subscribe/unsubscribe, list subscriptions, subscriber counts as derived data)
Comments CRUD (post/edit/delete), comment threads/replies, pin/heart flags as metadata
Reactions and engagement metadata (like/dislike, share events, save-to-playlist, watch-later)
Notifications as records (new upload alerts, comment replies) and read/unread states
Captions/subtitles as text tracks metadata (language, track list, upload/delete text file as plain text)
Video settings metadata (quality preference flag, age restriction flag, made-for-kids flag, allowed embedding flag)
Content moderation workflows (report flags, review queue, remove/restore, strike records, block users)
Creator studio-like management APIs (list uploads, drafts/scheduled items, bulk update metadata)
Basic analytics with synthesized aggregates (views/likes/comments over time, audience geography buckets, retention as synthetic percentages)
Search over a small synthesized catalog using simple filters/sorting (by title/tags/date) without real ranking complexity
non_simulatable_features: Actual video storage/streaming, adaptive bitrate playback, CDN delivery, buffering behavior
Real transcoding/encoding pipelines, thumbnails generated from video frames, HDR/codec/device-specific playback
Copyright detection/content ID matching and audio/video fingerprinting
Personalized recommendations and home feed ranking driven by large-scale ML models and real user behavior
Large-scale semantic search relevance, spam detection at scale, and anti-abuse systems
Live streaming at scale (latency, chat synchronization, stream health), real-time concurrent viewer handling
Precise watch-time measurement and fraud-resistant view counting, advertiser-grade analytics accuracy
Ad serving ecosystem (real-time bidding, targeting, pacing, measurement) as implemented in production
Community dynamics based on real-world trends and creator ecosystems (cannot be faithfully synthesized beyond toy data)
Multi-language auto-translation/auto-captioning and speech recognition quality

name: GitHub
description: GitHub is the premier code hosting platform used by millions of developers worldwide for version control and collaboration. Users can create repositories, manage branches, commit code changes, and track project versions using Git. The platform facilitates team collaboration through pull requests, code reviews, issue tracking, and project boards. It also supports CI/CD workflows, security scanning, and documentation hosting through GitHub Pages.
suitability_reasoning: Many GitHub workflows are structured CRUD over clearly defined entities (repos, issues, PRs, comments, labels, projects, releases, permissions) and can be synthesized with realistic fake data. However, core value also depends on non-trivial git semantics (diffs, merges, history, branching), code content, search/indexing, and integrations/automation that are difficult to simulate faithfully without implementing substantial git and execution infrastructure.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (CRUD)
Organizations/teams, membership, and roles/permissions (CRUD)
Repositories as metadata objects (create/archive/delete, settings, visibility)
Repository collaborators and access control lists
Issues: create/update/close, assignments, milestones, labels, states, priorities
Issue comments and reactions
Pull requests as workflow objects: open/close/merge state flags, reviewers, review statuses (approve/changes requested), threaded review comments (as structured comments)
Basic branch metadata (branch names, default branch, protection rule records as configuration data)
Tags/releases as metadata (version strings, release notes as short text, attached artifact metadata)
Projects/boards: columns, cards, issue/PR associations, status fields
Notifications/watch/subscription state (per repo/thread)
Webhooks as configuration objects and delivery logs (simulated)
Actions/CI: workflow run records, job records, statuses, timestamps, logs as short text placeholders
Packages/container registry metadata (package names, versions, download counts as synthetic metrics)
Security advisories/vulnerability alerts as structured records (severity, affected versions, status)
Wiki/Pages configuration and page metadata (titles, last-updated timestamps; content can be short placeholder text)
non_simulatable_features: True git object model and operations (commits/trees/blobs), integrity, and packfiles
Accurate diffs, patch generation, blame, and history traversal at scale
Realistic merge behavior and conflict detection/resolution
Hosting and serving actual repository code content with full fidelity
Code search and advanced query ranking (requires indexing engine and relevance behavior)
Running real CI/CD workloads (execution environment, runners, secrets, caching, artifacts) beyond status simulation
Security scanning that depends on code analysis (CodeQL, secret scanning, dependency graph accuracy) without implementing analyzers and package resolution
Dependabot-style automated update PR generation with real ecosystem resolution
Full-featured GitHub Pages static site generation/hosting pipeline (beyond configuration/metadata)
Third-party integrations marketplace behaviors and OAuth app flows with real external services

name: Gmail
description: Gmail is Google's email service offering powerful email management and organization tools. Users can compose, send, receive, and organize emails using labels, folders, and advanced search capabilities. The platform includes features like spam filtering, email threading, attachment handling, and integration with Google Calendar and Drive. Users can also set up filters and rules, manage multiple email accounts, create signatures, and use smart compose for faster email writing.
suitability_reasoning: Gmail’s core object model (messages, threads, labels, contacts, drafts, filters, attachments, settings) is highly structured and can be synthesized for CRUD-style workflows. However, several hallmark capabilities—spam/phishing classification, advanced search relevance, deliverability, real email routing, and AI-assisted writing—depend on external services, large-scale indexing, or ML inference that is not meaningfully reproducible in a lightweight simulation. A useful simulator can still cover most user task flows by focusing on inbox organization, message lifecycle, and rule-based automation with deterministic behavior.
simulatable_features: User accounts and mailbox settings (display name, signature, vacation responder, forwarding toggles as configuration)
Compose/save/update/send drafts (draft lifecycle)
Receive/store emails as synthesized messages with headers (from/to/cc/bcc), subject, snippet/body (short text), timestamps
Threading as a deterministic grouping model (e.g., by thread_id / in-reply-to references)
Inbox operations: list messages/threads, mark read/unread, star/unstar, archive/unarchive, delete/restore, move to trash
Labels/folders: create/update/delete labels; apply/remove labels to messages; system labels (INBOX, SENT, DRAFT, TRASH, SPAM) as states
Attachments metadata CRUD (filename, size, mime_type, attachment_id) and association to messages (without real binary content)
Basic search/filtering over structured fields (from, to, subject keywords, label, has_attachment, date ranges) using simple SQL queries
Contacts CRUD (name, email addresses) and autocomplete from stored contacts
Filters/rules CRUD (conditions + actions) with deterministic application to new incoming messages (e.g., auto-label, auto-archive)
Multiple account configuration (linked accounts as entities; switching active account context)
Blocklist/allowlist settings and simplistic sender-based spam rules (deterministic)
Conversation actions: reply/forward modeled as creation of new messages linked to a thread
non_simulatable_features: Real email delivery and routing over SMTP/IMAP, including deliverability, bounces, and inter-provider messaging behavior
High-quality spam/phishing/malware detection and classification comparable to Gmail (ML- and reputation-based)
Advanced full-text search with ranking, fuzzy matching, relevance, and large-scale indexing behavior
Smart Compose / AI-assisted writing and other ML-driven suggestions
True attachment handling for large binaries, virus scanning, and content-based previews (PDF/image rendering)
Deep integrations with Google Drive/Calendar (real file storage, sharing permissions, event creation) beyond mocked metadata
Security features tied to real identity infrastructure (OAuth flows, 2FA, device trust, risk-based authentication)
Real-time push notifications and sync semantics across devices/clients (can be approximated but not faithfully reproduced)

name: Twitter/X
description: Twitter (now X) is a real-time social media platform for sharing short messages and engaging in public conversations. Users can post tweets with text, images, videos, or polls, follow other users to see their updates, and engage through likes, retweets, and replies. The platform supports direct messaging for private conversations, trending topics exploration, hashtag usage, and list creation for organizing followed accounts. Users can also customize their profile, manage privacy settings, and use advanced search features.
suitability_reasoning: Twitter/X has many structured, CRUD-friendly entities (users, posts, follows, likes, reposts, replies, DMs, lists, blocks/mutes, reports) that can be synthesized realistically in a SQLite-backed REST API. However, core product value depends on large-scale public discourse and discovery quality: real-time global trends, ranking algorithms for timelines/search, spam/abuse dynamics, and rich media content delivery are difficult to simulate meaningfully without a real corpus, real-time signals, and complex ranking/integrity systems.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update profile fields, avatars as metadata, verification flag as state)
Posting/editing/deleting short posts (text-only or media metadata placeholders)
Replies/threads (parent-child relationships among posts)
Likes/favorites (user-post reactions) and unlikes
Reposts/retweets and quote-posts (relationships to original post)
Follows/unfollows and follower/following lists
Mentions and hashtag tagging as indexed fields on posts
Bookmarks and user collections of posts
Lists (create/update/delete lists, add/remove members, list timelines based on membership)
Direct messages (1:1 or group chats, message CRUD, read receipts as state)
Notifications/activity feed (new follower, like, repost, reply, mention) generated from stored events
Privacy and safety settings (protected account flag, who-can-reply settings, message request settings as state)
Blocks and mutes (relationship edges affecting visibility in simulated endpoints)
Basic reporting workflows (create report records, moderation status fields, enforcement actions as state)
Basic analytics counters (impressions/engagements as synthesized numeric fields or derived aggregates)
Scheduled posts (create/update schedule, publish job as simulated action)
Account management state (suspension, deactivation, reactivation) with audit fields
non_simulatable_features: Meaningful real-time trending topics driven by global-scale activity and time-sensitive external events
High-quality ranking and personalization for Home/For You timeline (ML-based relevance, graph signals, real engagement patterns)
Advanced search relevance/ranking comparable to production (full-text ranking, freshness, authority, anti-spam scoring at scale)
Spam/bot detection and trust/safety enforcement quality comparable to real platform (requires sophisticated models and adversarial data)
Authentic large-scale public conversation dynamics (network effects, virality, breaking news propagation)
Media hosting/streaming for images/videos and real content delivery constraints (can only simulate metadata and URLs)
Ads/auction-based targeting and billing behavior (real ad marketplace and optimization not realistically synthesized)
Cross-platform integrations and real external link previews/cards at internet scale

name: LinkedIn
description: LinkedIn is the world's largest professional networking platform connecting professionals and businesses. Users can create detailed professional profiles showcasing their work experience, skills, education, and accomplishments. The platform enables job searching with advanced filters, networking with industry professionals, publishing articles, and engaging with professional content. Users can also receive and give recommendations, join professional groups, follow companies, and participate in industry discussions.
suitability_reasoning: LinkedIn contains many structured, synthesizable entities (profiles, connections, jobs, applications, companies, messages) that map well to CRUD APIs and relational data. However, core user value also depends on hard-to-simulate systems like a personalized feed ranking, large-scale search relevance, trust/safety enforcement, and rich long-form content quality; these can be approximated but not faithfully reproduced without complex ranking/ML and moderation pipelines.
simulatable_features: User accounts and authentication (sign-up, login, password reset tokens)
Professional profiles (headline, about, location, open-to-work, contact info)
Experience, education, certifications, projects, publications (CRUD on profile sections)
Skills, endorsements, and proficiency levels (add/remove skills, endorse/unendorse)
Connections graph (send/accept/ignore invitations, remove connection, connection notes)
Following (follow/unfollow people, companies, hashtags)
Company pages (company profile, locations, admins, updates)
Job postings (create/edit/close jobs, requirements, compensation ranges, location/remote flags)
Job search filters and saved searches (query parameters and stored filter sets)
Job applications (apply, withdraw, application status pipeline, attached resume metadata)
Recruiter workflows (candidates, shortlists, stages, notes, tags, outreach messages)
Messaging (1:1 and group threads, send messages, read receipts flags, attachments metadata)
Groups (create/join/leave groups, roles, group posts, comments)
Posts and short-form updates (create/edit/delete posts, reactions/likes, comments, reposts)
Recommendations (request recommendation, write/approve/hide recommendation)
Events (create events, RSVP status, attendee lists)
Notifications (generate and mark read/unread for events like invites, messages, reactions)
Blocking/reporting objects (block user, report content with reason codes and statuses)
Basic analytics counters (profile views count, post impressions as synthetic aggregates)
Ads objects as CRUD (campaigns, creatives metadata, budgets, targeting fields as enums)
non_simulatable_features: High-fidelity personalized feed generation and ranking (ML-based relevance, virality, dwell time optimization)
Realistic search ranking across people/jobs/companies with relevance, expertise scoring, and anti-spam tuning at scale
Trust & safety / anti-fraud and anti-spam detection (bot detection, coordinated inauthentic behavior, account integrity)
Authentic identity verification and real-world employment/education verification processes
Meaningful long-form article ecosystem quality (author credibility, nuanced industry content at scale)
Large-scale recommendations ("People You May Know", "Jobs You May Be Interested In") driven by production-grade graph/ML models
Ad auction, pacing, attribution, conversion measurement, and real billing/tax handling
Compliance-heavy data governance workflows (GDPR/CCPA operational processes, legal holds) beyond basic CRUD flags
Real-time insights derived from massive platform activity (benchmarking, labor market analytics) that rely on real population data
Third-party integrations and enterprise SSO/SCIM provisioning behaviors as implemented in real organizations

name: Reddit
description: Reddit is a massive discussion platform organized into thousands of topic-based communities called subreddits. Users can browse content, post text, links, images, or videos in relevant subreddits, and participate in discussions through comments. The platform uses an upvote/downvote system for content ranking, supports threaded discussions, and offers both public and private communities. Users can customize their feed, save posts, award exceptional content, and use search features to find specific discussions or communities.
suitability_reasoning: Reddit’s core entities (users, subreddits, posts, comments, votes, moderation actions) are highly structured and can be synthesized with realistic relationships and states, making many workflows simulatable via CRUD APIs. However, several core-value aspects depend on hard-to-replicate dynamics: large-scale emergent content quality, ranking behavior across time, spam/abuse patterns, rich media hosting, and search relevance across a massive corpus. A useful simulation is feasible if scoped to community management, posting, commenting, voting, moderation, and basic feed generation with deterministic rules rather than true Reddit-scale discovery and relevance.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update preferences, bio, settings)
Subreddit lifecycle (create, update rules, public/restricted/private status, subscribe/unsubscribe)
Role and permissions management (moderators, approved users, bans, mutes)
Posts CRUD (text/link/media-metadata posts, flair, NSFW/spoiler flags, crosspost references)
Comments CRUD (threaded replies, edit history metadata, lock state)
Voting and score tracking (upvote/downvote per user, aggregate score, vote state)
Simple ranking/feed APIs (hot/new/top with rule-based sorting, pagination, time windows)
Content moderation workflows (remove/approve content, distinguish/sticky posts, lock threads)
Reporting workflow (user reports, mod review queue, resolution states)
User-to-user messaging (DMs) and modmail-style conversations (threaded messages, read states)
Notifications (mentions, replies, mod actions, subscriptions; unread counts)
Saved posts/comments and user collections (save/unsave, list saved items)
Awards as structured transactions (award types, counts, giver/receiver logs; without real economy)
Basic search APIs over synthesized data (substring/tag-based search for posts/subreddits/users)
Analytics-lite endpoints (post view counters, subscriber counts, activity summaries—synthetic)
non_simulatable_features: Authentic large-scale content corpus and long-form/high-quality discussion content at real Reddit diversity and volume
Real-world relevance and nuanced search ranking (full-text search quality, semantic relevance, learning-to-rank)
True “hot” ranking dynamics driven by massive concurrent traffic, velocity, and anti-manipulation heuristics
Spam/brigading/ban-evasion detection and other ML/heuristic trust & safety systems as deployed at scale
Real media hosting/streaming and media processing (video encoding, image pipelines), beyond metadata placeholders
External link previews, embeds, and integrations that require live web fetching
Real-time event-driven trends (front page reflecting breaking events) without external feeds
Personalized recommendations based on large-scale behavioral models (subreddit/post recommendations)
Reddit’s real economy/payment processing for coins/paid awards/subscriptions (can be mocked, not faithfully replicated)

name: Spotify
description: Spotify is a popular music streaming service with millions of songs, albums, and podcasts. Users can search for music by artist, song, or album, create and manage custom playlists, and discover new content through personalized recommendations. The platform supports following favorite artists, sharing music with friends, accessing lyrics, and controlling playback quality. Users can also save music for offline listening, use collaborative playlists, explore curated playlists by mood or genre, and listen to podcasts.
suitability_reasoning: Spotify has many structured, CRUD-friendly entities (users, tracks metadata, playlists, follows, saves, subscriptions, playback devices/sessions) that can be synthesized and exposed via REST APIs. However, the core product value depends on non-synthesizable assets and systems—licensed audio/podcast media delivery, real recommendations, search relevance over a massive corpus, lyrics licensing, and playback/DRM/offline media handling—so a simulation can capture management workflows but not true streaming behavior or content quality.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update preferences, region, plan)
Music/podcast catalog metadata (artists, albums, tracks, episodes, genres, durations, popularity scores)
Search endpoints over synthesized metadata (basic filtering, pagination)
Playlist CRUD (create, rename, description, cover metadata, privacy)
Playlist items CRUD (add/remove/reorder tracks/episodes, bulk operations)
Collaborative playlists (add collaborators, roles, edit history metadata)
Library management (save/unsave tracks, albums, artists, episodes; liked songs)
Following/relationships (follow/unfollow artists/users, list followers/following)
Sharing links and activity metadata (share events, shared-to targets as records)
Playback state as data (devices list, current queue, repeat/shuffle flags, last played, play history)
Quality/settings CRUD (streaming quality setting, explicit-content toggle, notifications)
Offline availability flags (mark playlist/album as 'downloaded' status without real media)
User listening history and statistics (recently played, top artists/tracks over time ranges)
Subscriptions and billing records (plan changes, renewals, invoices as synthetic records)
Curated playlists as synthetic collections (mood/genre tags, editorial owner)
non_simulatable_features: Actual audio/podcast streaming and content delivery (licensed media files, buffering, CDN behavior)
DRM, device authorization constraints, and real offline downloads (encrypted media storage)
Personalized recommendations (Discover Weekly, Daily Mix) driven by ML and real listening graph
High-quality full-text/phonetic search relevance and ranking at Spotify-scale
Lyrics display (licensed lyric content and synchronization timing/word-level karaoke)
Audio analysis features tied to real signal processing (beat/tempo/key from real audio)
Real-time social listening sessions with synchronized playback across devices
Podcast ad insertion/measurement and rights-managed distribution specifics

name: Expedia
description: Expedia is a comprehensive online travel booking platform for planning and booking trips worldwide. Users can search and compare flights, hotels, rental cars, and vacation packages based on dates, destinations, and preferences. The platform provides detailed information including prices, reviews, photos, and amenities for each option. Users can manage their bookings, view itineraries, access mobile boarding passes, earn rewards points, and receive travel alerts. It also offers features like flexible date searches, bundle deals, and travel insurance options.
suitability_reasoning: Expedia’s core workflows are structured and transactional (searching inventory, pricing, booking, managing reservations, payments, rewards), which map well to synthesizable relational data and CRUD-style REST APIs. The main gaps are features that depend on real-time third-party availability/pricing, airline/hotel operational systems, and rich media content, but these can be approximated with static or generated data in a simulation.
simulatable_features: User accounts and traveler profiles (personal info, preferences, saved travelers)
Destination, airport, airline, hotel, car-rental location catalogs
Search requests with filters (dates, passengers, cabin, stops, hotel stars, amenities, car class) and paginated results
Synthetic flight/hotel/car inventory with generated fares/rates, fare rules, room types, cancellation policies, and taxes/fees breakdown
Vacation package creation (bundle flight+hotel+car), bundle pricing logic, and package cart management
Shopping cart, checkout flow, saved payment methods (tokenized placeholders), billing addresses
Booking creation/updates/cancellation for flights, hotels, cars, activities (status changes, refund amounts, policy enforcement)
Itinerary management (trip timeline, confirmation numbers, vouchers, traveler assignments)
Reviews and ratings CRUD (short text reviews, star ratings, helpful votes) with moderation status
Travel insurance quoting/selection (plan catalog, premiums, coverage attributes) and attaching insurance to a booking
Rewards program (member tier, points accrual/redemption ledger, coupons/credits)
Alerts and notifications (email/SMS/push records, subscription preferences, travel reminders) using synthesized event triggers
Customer support cases (tickets, messages, escalation status, resolution codes)
Price tracking/watchlists and stored searches (simple rule-based alerts on synthetic price changes)
non_simulatable_features: Real-time availability and pricing sourced from airlines/hotels/GDS systems (live inventory, last-seat availability, true dynamic pricing)
Actual ticket issuance, airline PNR synchronization, and operational flight updates from carriers (true gate changes, delays from real feeds)
Mobile boarding passes that are valid for airport/airline systems (real barcodes tied to issued tickets)
Fraud detection, identity verification, and payment authorization/settlement with real payment networks
True geospatial accuracy for maps, routing, and live location-based services (can be approximated but not truly replicated)
Rich media assets at scale (real hotel photos, user-uploaded images, verified media licensing)
Authentic third-party review verification and provenance (e.g., verified stays across providers)
Integration-dependent features like call-center telephony, live chat with humans, and partner extranet management (can be mocked but not faithfully reproduced)

name: Facebook
description: Facebook is a social networking platform where users create profiles, connect with friends, and share posts, photos, videos, Stories, Reels, and live streams in a personalized News Feed. It offers Groups, Pages, Events, and Marketplace for community building, broadcasting, event planning, and local buying/selling, with Messenger integrated for private and group chats. Users can react, comment, share, manage privacy settings, and businesses can run targeted ads, manage pages, and access analytics.
suitability_reasoning: Many Facebook workflows are CRUD over structured entities (users, posts, comments, groups, events, listings, messages) and can be synthesized. However, core value depends on large-scale feed ranking/recommendations, social graph dynamics, moderation, ad targeting/auction delivery, and rich media (photos/video/live) behavior, which are difficult to reproduce meaningfully without real content, models, and platform-scale infrastructure. A useful simulation is achievable by focusing on management and interaction flows rather than authentic feed relevance and media delivery.
simulatable_features: User accounts/profiles (create/update profile fields, settings)
Friend requests, friendships, blocks, follows (social graph CRUD)
Posts (text/link metadata), editing, deleting, visibility settings
Comments and replies on posts
Reactions (like/love/etc.) and counts
Shares/reposts (as references to original content)
Saved items/bookmarks
Groups: create groups, membership requests, roles (admin/mod/member), group posts
Pages: create/manage pages, page posts, roles (admin/editor), basic insights counters (synthetic)
Events: create events, RSVPs, guest lists, reminders
Marketplace: listings (title/price/category/location), availability status, inquiries
Messenger-like messaging: 1:1 and group threads, messages, read receipts (synthetic), attachments metadata
Notifications: generate activity notifications (new comment, reaction, invite, message)
Reporting/flagging content (create reports, status workflow)
Privacy controls: per-post audience, profile visibility toggles, blocked users
Basic search endpoints over synthetic entities (users/pages/groups/listings) with simple filtering
non_simulatable_features: Authentic News Feed ranking/personalization and recommendation algorithms at scale
Real ad targeting, auction mechanics, delivery optimization, conversion attribution, and third-party tracking integrations
Real-time integrity systems (spam detection, coordinated inauthentic behavior detection, bot mitigation)
High-fidelity content moderation decisions using ML and large policy knowledge bases
Media hosting/streaming behaviors: photo/video transcoding, live streaming, Reels/Stories playback and creation pipelines
Large-scale social graph discovery features (People You May Know) driven by real behavioral signals
Cross-app interoperability with Instagram/WhatsApp and real device-level push notification delivery
Accurate analytics based on real impressions/reach with complex deduplication and measurement

name: Yahoo
description: Yahoo is a web portal and online media platform offering personalized news, finance, sports, entertainment, and weather. Users can read articles and watch videos, track markets with real-time quotes, charts, portfolios, and alerts in Yahoo Finance, follow live scores, schedules, standings, and fantasy leagues in Yahoo Sports, access Yahoo Mail for email with contacts and calendar, use the search engine to find web content, and customize a homepage with topics and local weather. Signing in with a Yahoo account enables personalization and syncing across web and mobile apps.
suitability_reasoning: Yahoo bundles several products. Many user-management workflows (mail, contacts, calendar, personalization settings, watchlists/portfolios, fantasy league rosters) are structured and CRUD-friendly with synthesizable data. However, major core value areas rely on non-synthesizable or hard-to-replicate components: high-volume editorial news/video content, real-time market quotes, live sports feeds, and web search ranking/indexing. A simulated environment can cover account-centric workflows well, but cannot faithfully reproduce the live/content aspects without reducing scope to synthetic datasets.
simulatable_features: User accounts, sessions, profiles, preferences (topics, regions, language, homepage modules)
Homepage customization (add/remove/reorder modules, saved locations for weather)
Synthetic news/feed objects (headline, summary, category, publish time) with bookmarking, 'save for later', and following topics/sources
Comments/reactions on articles (create/update/delete comments, like/dislike) using short synthesized text
Yahoo Finance portfolios/watchlists (create portfolios, add symbols, lots, cost basis, notes)
Finance alerts and notifications (price threshold alerts, earnings date reminders) against synthetic quote time-series
Historical price/quote datasets and chart candles using plausible synthesized OHLCV data (not real-time)
Bills/receipts/expense tags for finance-style organization (if modeling personal finance add-ons) with synthetic transactions
Yahoo Sports favorites (teams/leagues), schedules/standings data using synthetic seasons, games, and stats
Fantasy league management (create league, invite users, draft picks, roster CRUD, waiver claims, scoring rules) with synthetic player pools and stats
Yahoo Mail core mailbox workflows (folders/labels, messages, threads, read/unread, move, delete, search within mailbox, spam/trash)
Mail composition and sending within the simulated system (outbox/sent items), attachments as metadata בלבד
Contacts/address book (CRUD contacts, groups, import/export as synthetic data)

name: Instagram

name: Indeed
description: Indeed is a global job search platform that aggregates listings from employers, job boards, and company career pages. Users can search and filter jobs by title, location, salary, experience level, remote options, and more; create a profile; upload a resume; apply directly through Indeed; save jobs; and set email or mobile alerts. name: Duo Security (Cisco Duo)
description: Duo Security is a cloud-based access security platform focused on Zero Trust. It provides multi-factor authentication (MFA) with Duo Push, TOTP, SMS/phone, and hardware tokens; passwordless and phishing-resistant authentication via FIDO2/WebAuthn and passkeys; and single sign-on (SSO) for web and cloud apps. name: Stack Overflow
description: Stack Overflow is a Q&A platform for developers where users ask programming questions, tag them by technology, and post code and explanations. name: GitLab
description: GitLab is a DevOps platform centered on Git repositories, issues, and CI/CD pipelines. name: Uber Eats

name: QuickBooks
description: QuickBooks is an accounting and bookkeeping platform for small businesses. name: Jira

name: Google Calendar

Tipping (add/update tip pre/post delivery) and shopper rating
Returns/refunds and issue reporting (missing/damaged/wrong item cases)
Notifications as stored events (order updates, substitution requests) retrievable via API
Basic inventory availability flags and per-item limits (simulated stock counts or availability states)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time inventory and price accuracy from retailers (continuous synchronization with store POS systems)
Real-time GPS mapping, turn-by-turn routing, and accurate ETAs based on traffic and shopper location
Actual payment processing, card network interactions, fraud detection, and chargeback workflows (can only be mocked)
Integration with external identity verification, device risk signals, and anti-abuse systems (can be approximated with flags)
High-quality search ranking, personalized recommendations, and dynamic merchandising driven by large-scale ML (can be simplified)
Real-world shopper behavior and operational constraints (in-store delays, item-level scanning accuracy) beyond scripted simulation
Push notification delivery via APNs/FCM and SMS/telephony delivery confirmations (can be represented as queued events)
Live customer support call/chat operations with human agents (can be simulated as ticket CRUD, not real staffing)

name: Patreon
description: Patreon is a membership platform that allows creators to offer subscription-based access to content and benefits. Creators set up pages with tiers, pricing, and rewards, then publish posts, audio, video, and other perks for patrons. Patrons can subscribe, manage memberships across creators, access exclusive content, comment, and message creators. The platform manages payments, billing cycles, and fraud checks, while creators can view analytics, payouts, and patron lists.
suitability_reasoning: Patreon’s core data model (creators, memberships, tiers, billing cycles, posts metadata, comments, messages, payouts) is highly structured and can be synthesized well via CRUD APIs. However, the platform’s primary value includes rich media content hosting/delivery (audio/video/images), real payment networks, fraud/risk systems, and some nuanced billing behaviors (proration, charge failures, disputes) that are hard to replicate faithfully without external services—though they can be approximated with simulated states and webhooks.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, roles (creator vs patron), authentication tokens
Creator pages and settings (bio, categories, goals, social links)
Membership tiers (price, benefits list, limits, availability, tier status)
Patron subscriptions (start/end dates, renewal date, status: active/canceled/past_due)
Benefits/perks catalog and entitlement mapping (which tier grants which perks)
Posts as structured records (title, short body/summary, publish status, visibility by tier, tags)
Comments and reactions/likes on posts
Direct messages/conversations between patrons and creators (text-only)
Billing objects: invoices, charges, payment attempts, receipts (synthetic), failed-payment states
Refunds, cancellations, pauses, upgrades/downgrades (modeled as state transitions)
Payout accounts (simulated), payout schedules, payout batches, payout transactions/ledger
Creator patron list management (filters by tier/status, join date, lifetime value fields as synthetic)
Promotions/coupons (discounts, redemption limits, validity windows)
Notifications and activity feed entries (new post, charge processed, message received)
Basic analytics dashboards (MRR, churn, patron counts, revenue by tier) using synthesized aggregates
Access control checks for exclusive content (entitlements by tier/status)
Moderation actions (delete comment, block user, restrict patron)
non_simulatable_features: Actual media hosting/streaming and DRM-like enforcement for audio/video (can only simulate metadata/URLs)
Real payment processing, card network interactions, bank transfers, tax/VAT remittance, and compliance (KYC/AML)
Fraud detection/risk scoring and chargeback/dispute workflows as performed by real processors (only mock outcomes)
Accurate replication of complex billing edge cases across regions (proration rules, currency conversion, retries, regional taxes) beyond simplified simulation
Email/SMS/push delivery through real providers (can simulate queued notifications but not real delivery)
Creator content quality/discovery/recommendation systems driven by real user behavior (only static or rule-based mocks)

name: KAYAK
description: KAYAK is a travel search and booking aggregator that lets users search flights, hotels, and rental cars across multiple providers. Users can filter by price, times, airlines, stops, amenities, and ratings, then click through to complete bookings or book directly when available. Features include fare alerts, price tracking, trip planning, and itinerary management. The platform compares options, saves searches, and aggregates reservations into unified trip views.
suitability_reasoning: Most core workflows can be represented with structured, synthesizable entities (flights/hotels/cars, quotes, filters, bookings, itineraries, alerts, providers) and typical CRUD/state transitions. The main hard-to-simulate parts are real-time pricing/availability, provider redirect/affiliate attribution, and any ranking/recommendation logic based on proprietary or live supply.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, traveler details, preferences (airlines, seat class, loyalty programs)
Search sessions with parameters and filters (origin/destination, dates, passengers, cabin, stops, times, amenities, ratings)
Synthesized result sets for flights/hotels/cars with fares, schedules, policies, amenities, ratings, and provider metadata
Sorting and filtering over synthesized results (price, duration, departure/arrival windows, stops, airline, hotel stars, car class)
Saved searches and recently viewed items
Fare/price alerts and price tracking history for a route/date (create/update/delete alert, trigger notification events)
Trips/itinerary objects (create trip, add/remove itinerary items, day-by-day organization, notes)
Reservation aggregation (manually add bookings; import via simulated email/PNR upload; attach e-tickets/vouchers as metadata)
Booking lifecycle for direct-booking simulations (hold, booked, ticketed, cancelled, refunded) with confirmation numbers
Traveler documents/contacts (passport metadata fields, emergency contact info) as stored structured data
Provider catalog management (airlines, hotel chains, car rental companies) and mappings between offers and providers
Customer support tickets related to bookings (issue types, status, messages) as CRUD objects
non_simulatable_features: Live, real-time pricing and availability across external providers and GDS systems
True metasearch coverage and completeness (crawling/partner feeds) and real supplier inventory
Redirect/click-through affiliate tracking, attribution, and real payment settlement with third parties
Accurate, provider-enforced fare rules and ticketing constraints as they change in real time
Proprietary ranking algorithms and personalization based on large-scale behavioral data (can be approximated but not replicated faithfully)
Real-time disruption handling (delays/cancellations) based on live airline/airport operational feeds
Authentic user-generated reviews at scale and moderation/anti-fraud systems (can be faked, but not meaningfully equivalent)
Interactive maps with real-time map tiles/traffic and geospatial data licensing constraints (only basic static geo can be simulated)

name: Lyft
description: Lyft is a ride-hailing platform where users set pickup and dropoff locations, choose ride options, view pricing and ETAs, and request, track, or cancel rides. Riders can split fares, tip drivers, rate trips, and manage payment methods and preferences. Drivers manage availability, accept rides, navigate routes, and review earnings and incentives. Safety features include trip sharing, emergency options, and support flows for reporting issues.
suitability_reasoning: Lyft’s core workflows are structured and state-driven (users, drivers, vehicles, ride requests, quotes, trips, payments, ratings, support tickets) and can be represented with synthesizable geospatial data, timestamps, prices, and status transitions. While true real-time maps, live GPS, and telephony/emergency integrations can’t be fully replicated, their effects can be simulated with generated location updates and deterministic ETA/pricing rules.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (rider/driver), preferences, saved places
Driver onboarding data (documents metadata, vehicle records, availability status)
Pickup/dropoff location management (addresses, lat/long), ride request creation
Ride options catalog (vehicle types, capacity, accessibility flags), eligibility rules
Fare estimation/quotes (base fare, distance/time components, surge multiplier, fees)
ETA estimation (driver distance, traffic factor), driver matching/dispatch simulation
Trip lifecycle state machine (requested/accepted/arriving/in_progress/completed/canceled/no_show) with timestamps
In-trip location updates stream (CRUD as time-series points or periodic status updates)
Cancellation flows and fees, no-show handling, dispute flags
Payments: payment methods (tokenized placeholders), authorizations/captures/refunds, receipts
Fare split configuration (participants, split amounts/percentages), settlement records
Tipping after trip, promotions/credits, loyalty or coupons
Ratings and feedback for driver/rider, tags and short comments
Driver earnings ledger (trip payouts, bonuses, adjustments), incentives programs definitions and progress
Support flows: issue categories, tickets, chat transcripts (short text), resolution status
Safety features as records: trip sharing links/tokens, scheduled check-ins, incident reports, audit logs
non_simulatable_features: True real-time GPS accuracy and continuous background location behavior at scale
Live map rendering, turn-by-turn navigation, and route optimization based on real road networks/traffic
Actual real-time traffic conditions and ETAs derived from live telemetry
Phone/SMS push communications with real carriers (masked numbers), real push notification delivery
Emergency services integration (911/third-party safety providers) and verified identity/background checks
Fraud detection, risk scoring, and dynamic pricing tuned by proprietary ML models and real supply/demand signals

name: Square
description: Square is a payments and point-of-sale platform for businesses. Merchants create catalogs of items with prices and taxes, accept in-person and online payments, issue refunds, and view transaction histories. They can manage customers, invoices, and recurring payments, as well as track sales, inventory, and basic analytics. Additional modules support online stores, appointments, and staff management. Admins configure deposits, fees, hardware, and security settings.
suitability_reasoning: Square’s core workflows are structured, transactional CRUD over synthesizable entities (catalog, customers, orders, payments, refunds, invoices, inventory, staff, schedules). A simulator can model end-to-end merchant operations with realistic fake data, including states (authorized/captured/refunded), fees, deposits, and reports. The main non-simulatable parts are real payment network interactions, card-present hardware behavior, fraud/risk decisions, and compliance/KYC processes—these can be approximated but not faithfully reproduced without external systems.
simulatable_features: Merchant accounts/locations management (business profile, store locations, hours, tax settings)
Item catalog CRUD (items, variations, modifiers, categories, images as metadata, pricing, taxes)
Inventory CRUD (stock counts, adjustments, low-stock thresholds, inventory history)
Customers CRM CRUD (profiles, contact info, notes, groups/segments, saved cards as tokens)
Orders and carts (line items, discounts, tips, service charges, order states)
Payments lifecycle simulation (create payment intents, authorize/capture, void, partial/full refunds, chargebacks as records)
Transaction history and ledger (payment records, fee records, net amounts, status timelines)
Invoices CRUD (draft/sent/paid/overdue, line items, due dates, reminders)
Recurring payments/subscriptions CRUD (plans, subscribers, billing cycles, renewals, cancellations, retries as state)
Deposits/payouts simulation (payout schedules, batches, bank accounts as masked identifiers, payout status)
Online store basics (product listings, checkout sessions, shipping options as structured data)
Appointments CRUD (services, staff assignment, availability blocks, bookings, cancellations, no-shows)
Staff management (employees, roles/permissions, schedules, timecards, wage rates as data fields)
Basic analytics endpoints (daily sales summaries, category performance, inventory turnover—derived from stored transactions)
Refunds management (reason codes, restocking flags, inventory reconciliation)
Discounts/coupons CRUD (promo codes, rules, validity windows, usage limits)
Tax rates and fee configurations as editable settings (for simulation purposes)
Security/admin settings CRUD (API keys as fake tokens, webhooks subscriptions, audit logs as records)
Hardware inventory registry (device records, assignment to locations, status as simulated)
non_simulatable_features: Real card network processing and settlement (Visa/Mastercard/Amex rails, interchange, real authorizations)
Card-present hardware behavior and secure elements (tap/chip/magstripe encryption, reader firmware, offline mode specifics)
Banking/KYC/underwriting workflows (identity verification, risk-based approvals, account holds)
Fraud detection and risk scoring based on proprietary models and external signals
True PCI compliance controls and secure storage/handling of PAN data (can only be represented by tokens/metadata)
Real-time third-party integrations and shipping/tax calculation services (live carrier rates, address validation)
Actual dispute/chargeback network timelines and evidence workflows (can be approximated as states but not replicated accurately)
Live push notifications, webhooks delivery guarantees, and distributed reliability behavior (can be mocked, not faithfully simulated)

name: Grubhub
description: Grubhub is an online food ordering and delivery platform. Users search and filter restaurants by cuisine, price, rating, and delivery options, browse menus, customize items, and add them to carts. At checkout they choose delivery or pickup, schedule times, use promo codes, and pay. Orders can be tracked, and users can rate and review restaurants and drivers, manage addresses and payment methods, and view order history. Restaurants handle incoming orders and menus via their own dashboard or POS integrations.
suitability_reasoning: Grubhub’s core workflows are structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (users, restaurants, menus, carts, orders, deliveries, payments metadata, promos, reviews). Real-time and third-party aspects (live driver GPS, payment processing, POS integrations) can be approximated with synthetic status/events, making it highly suitable for simulated API environments.
simulatable_features: User accounts and profiles (create/update preferences, contact info)
Address book management (multiple saved delivery addresses, instructions, geocoordinates)
Restaurant catalog (restaurants, hours, service areas, cuisine tags, fees, minimums)
Search/filter endpoints over restaurants (cuisine, price range, rating, distance, delivery/pickup availability)
Menu management (categories, items, option groups/modifiers, availability, item photos as metadata URLs)
Cart lifecycle (create cart, add/remove items, apply modifiers, quantities, special instructions)
Checkout flow (delivery vs pickup, scheduling, tipping, fees/taxes breakdown, promo code application)
Order creation and order history (statuses, timestamps, receipts/invoices, reorder)
Order tracking as state machine (placed/confirmed/preparing/picked_up/delivered/canceled with synthetic ETA updates)
Ratings and reviews for restaurants and drivers (stars, short text comments, moderation status)
Promotions (promo codes, eligibility rules, usage limits, discounts, credits)
Payment method tokens/metadata (store masked card info, default method) without real processing
Customer support artifacts (tickets, refunds/adjustments as ledger entries)
Merchant dashboard CRUD (restaurant profile, menu edits, hours, temporary item 86’ing, order acceptance/rejection)
Merchant order management (accept, adjust prep time, mark ready, cancel with reason codes)
Driver/dispatch simulation (driver profiles, assignment records, delivery tasks, status updates)
non_simulatable_features: Real payment processing and chargebacks (actual card networks, bank settlement, fraud/3DS flows)
Real-time GPS navigation and map routing accuracy (live location, traffic-aware ETAs)
True real-time marketplace supply/demand dynamics (actual driver availability and batching optimization)
Third-party POS integrations and webhooks with proprietary systems (Toast, Square, etc.) beyond mocked interfaces
Live phone/SMS/email deliverability and telephony features (call masking, OTP delivery) unless mocked
Authentic restaurant menu content, photos, and branding sourced from real businesses (can only be synthetic/placeholder)
Regulatory/identity verification workflows for drivers/merchants (KYC/background checks) beyond simplified statuses

name: Basecamp
description: Basecamp is a project management and team communication tool organized into projects, each containing to-dos, message boards, schedules, docs & files, and group chats. Users create tasks, assign them, set due dates, and track completion. Message boards host threaded discussions, while automatic check-ins and pings facilitate updates. Projects support file uploads, shared docs, and calendars. Admins manage teams, project access, and notifications across the workspace.
suitability_reasoning: Basecamp’s core workflows are structured, CRUD-heavy, and rely on synthesizable entities (projects, users, tasks, posts, comments, schedules, files metadata, notifications). Relationships and state transitions (assigned/completed/due, access control, subscriptions) are straightforward to model in SQLite and expose via REST. While real-time chat delivery and rich file contents are harder to replicate fully, most user tasks can be supported with simulated data and standard CRUD endpoints.
simulatable_features: User/workspace management (create users, roles, teams, preferences)
Project CRUD (create/update/archive projects, project membership/access lists)
To-dos and to-do lists (create tasks, assign users, due dates, status, completion tracking, recurring tasks)
Comments and activity feeds on tasks (threaded comments, mentions as metadata)
Message boards (create topics/posts, threaded replies, pin/close states, categories/tags)
Schedules/calendars (events, milestones, date ranges, reminders, iCal-style identifiers as metadata)
Docs (create/edit doc records, revisions/history as stored text blobs, collaborators list)
File management metadata (folders, files, versions, uploader, size, MIME type, download URL placeholders)
Group chat objects (rooms/channels, membership, message history storage, read/unread markers as state)
Automatic check-ins (questions, schedules, prompted responses, completion status)
Pings/direct messages as message objects (sender/recipient, content, timestamps, read receipts as flags)
Notifications/subscriptions (watch/unwatch, notification preferences, queued notification records)
Search over synthesized data using simple SQLite queries (by title/content fields, filters by project/type/date)
Audit/activity logs (who did what when, per project/workspace)
non_simulatable_features: True real-time chat behavior (presence, typing indicators, WebSocket delivery guarantees) beyond a simplified polling model
Rich file preview/processing (document rendering, image thumbnails, virus scanning, OCR) and realistic binary file storage at scale
Email/SMS/push notification delivery to real external services (can only simulate as queued/recorded sends)
Deep integrations with external tools (Google Drive/Slack/etc.) and their OAuth flows (can be stubbed but not faithfully replicated)
Advanced full-text search relevance ranking comparable to production search infrastructure (can only approximate with basic queries)
Complex permission edge-cases tied to enterprise identity providers/SSO and cross-workspace org policy enforcement (can be simplified)

name: Salesforce
description: Salesforce is a cloud-based CRM platform where users manage leads, accounts, contacts, opportunities, and cases. Sales teams log activities, track deal stages, forecast revenue, and create tasks and events. Service teams handle support cases with queues, priorities, and SLAs. Dashboards and reports visualize KPIs, while automation tools like workflows and flows trigger actions based on rules. Admins configure objects, fields, layouts, permissions, and integrations with external systems.
suitability_reasoning: Salesforce is dominated by structured, relational business data (leads, accounts, contacts, opportunities, cases, activities) and stateful workflows (stages, statuses, priorities, SLAs) that can be realistically synthesized and exercised through CRUD and query APIs. Key user tasks map cleanly to entity creation, updates, transitions, assignments, and reporting over those entities. The main limits are proprietary UI behaviors, complex metadata/configuration semantics, and advanced analytics/automation that may require a full rules engine or formula language to replicate faithfully.
simulatable_features: User authentication and basic org/account scoping
Users, roles, profiles, permission sets (simplified RBAC)
Leads CRUD (status, source, owner, scoring)
Accounts CRUD (industry, tier, addresses, relationships)
Contacts CRUD and association to accounts
Opportunities CRUD (stage transitions, amount, close date, probability)
Products/price books/line items (simplified) and opportunity products
Activities: tasks and events CRUD (due dates, reminders, attendees)
Notes and attachments metadata (file records without actual file content)
Cases CRUD (status, priority, queue/owner assignment, categories)
Case comments and internal notes
Queues and assignment rules (simplified deterministic routing)
SLAs/milestones as timestamps and state fields (start/stop/violated flags)
Forecasts as computed/snapshotted aggregates from opportunity data
Basic reporting endpoints: list, filter, group-by aggregates, KPI summaries
Dashboards as saved report references and layout metadata
Audit/history tracking as append-only change log records
Custom objects/fields metadata CRUD (subset): define objects, fields, picklists
Layouts/page settings metadata (simplified), record types, validation rules (simplified)
Webhooks/outbound messages simulation (event emission on CRUD/state changes)
Data import/export jobs (batch create/update)
non_simulatable_features: Full Salesforce metadata and platform behavior fidelity (Apex runtime, triggers, governor limits, multi-tenant execution semantics)
Complete Flow/Process Builder engine with branching, screen flows, loops, subflows, and connector semantics (beyond a simplified rules engine)
SOQL/SOSL full query language and optimization behavior (can approximate with limited filtering)
Einstein/AI features (lead scoring, predictions, next-best-action, generative summaries)
AppExchange ecosystem behavior and third-party managed packages
True real-time collaboration features (Slack integration, presence, complex notifications) beyond basic events
Pixel-perfect UI rendering behavior (Lightning components, dynamic forms, console workspace)
Advanced analytics products (Tableau/CRM Analytics) including semantic layers and complex visualizations
Telephony/CTI integrations and real call handling (can only simulate logs/metadata)
Email deliverability, inbound email-to-case parsing, and full templating/rendering engines (can simulate message records)
Document generation/e-signature integrations and actual file/content workflows (can simulate metadata and statuses)

name: ProtonMail
description: ProtonMail is a privacy-focused email service with end-to-end encryption. Users create mailboxes, send and receive emails, organize messages into folders and labels, and manage contacts. Security features include encrypted messages, optional password-protected emails to external recipients, two-factor authentication, and strict privacy controls. The interface supports search, filters, mail rules, and aliases, and users can adjust settings for signatures, auto-replies, and identity profiles.
suitability_reasoning: Much of ProtonMail’s workflow is structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (messages, folders/labels, contacts, settings, filters, aliases). However, core differentiators—end-to-end encryption, key management, secure external-message flows, and privacy/security guarantees—are hard to simulate faithfully without implementing real cryptography, MIME handling, and security constraints. A useful simulation is still possible by modeling metadata/state and simplified message content, but it won’t capture ProtonMail’s essential security properties.
simulatable_features: User accounts and mailbox profiles (identities, display names, signatures)
Compose/send/receive email objects with headers (from/to/cc/bcc/subject), body (short text), timestamps, and status flags (read/unread/starred)
Drafts, scheduled send (as a timestamp/state), and message threading/conversations (parent_id/thread_id)
Folders and labels creation/rename/delete; assign/remove labels; move messages between folders
Trash/archive/spam workflows; retention metadata; restore and permanent-delete operations
Contacts CRUD (names, emails, phones, notes) and contact groups
Aliases/addresses CRUD (create/disable/delete), default sending address selection
Mail rules/filters CRUD (conditions/actions) and applying rules to new messages in simulation
Auto-reply/vacation responder settings (enabled window, message text) and simple triggering behavior
Search over message metadata and body text using basic SQLite queries (not full-text ranking if not desired)
User settings CRUD (language, theme, notification prefs, default folder behaviors)
Two-factor authentication state toggles (enabled/disabled, recovery codes as stored strings) without real OTP validation
Session/API tokens and basic access control (ownership checks for mailbox resources)
Simple quota/billing plan fields (plan tier, storage used, message limits) with synthetic usage metrics
non_simulatable_features: True end-to-end encryption behavior (PGP-like keypairs, client-side encryption, cryptographic verification) with ProtonMail-specific implementation details
Real key management, key rotation, and secure storage semantics (including device trust and key transparency-style assurances)
Password-protected emails to external recipients with secure link flows and cryptographic enforcement
Authentic security guarantees (zero-access architecture, threat model protections) and side-channel/privacy properties
Full email protocol and MIME fidelity (SMTP/IMAP bridge behavior, attachments encoding, complex multipart messages) if required to match real clients
Advanced search relevance and indexing comparable to production (ranking, language-aware tokenization, encrypted search schemes)
Anti-spam/anti-phishing detection quality and reputation systems
Deliverability behaviors and real-world email routing/network interactions

name: Coinbase
description: Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange and wallet platform. Users verify identities, link payment methods, and buy, sell, and convert cryptocurrencies at market or recurring intervals. They can track portfolio balances and performance, view detailed transaction history, and transfer assets to and from external addresses. Watchlists and price alerts help monitor markets, while educational modules reward learning. Security settings include two-factor authentication, address whitelists, and withdrawal controls.
suitability_reasoning: Most core Coinbase workflows are structured CRUD over synthesizable entities (users, identities, payment methods, accounts, balances, orders, trades, transfers, addresses, alerts). Market data and blockchain settlement can be simulated with plausible price series and synthetic confirmations/status transitions. Only real-world dependencies (live prices, actual blockchain broadcasting, compliance/vendor checks) are non-simulatable in a purely synthetic environment.
simulatable_features: User accounts, profiles, and preferences CRUD
KYC/identity verification workflow states (document submissions metadata, review status, limits tiers) CRUD
Linked payment methods (bank accounts, cards) and verification states CRUD
Fiat accounts, crypto wallets, and portfolio balances (computed from synthetic transactions) CRUD
Trading pairs catalog, product metadata, and fee schedules CRUD
Market/limit orders, recurring buys, order lifecycle (created/open/filled/canceled) CRUD
Trade fills and transaction history (buys, sells, conversions, fees) CRUD
Internal transfers between user wallets/accounts CRUD
On-chain-like sends/receives with synthetic tx hashes, confirmations, network fees, and statuses CRUD
Address book, saved withdrawal addresses, and address whitelisting CRUD
Watchlists for assets and trading pairs CRUD
Price alerts/notifications rules (threshold, percent change, cadence) CRUD
Account limits (daily/weekly withdrawal/buy limits) and limit changes workflow CRUD
Security settings: 2FA enable/disable state, trusted devices/sessions, API keys (scopes), withdrawal holds/locks CRUD
Audit log / activity log entries CRUD
Educational modules catalog, quizzes completion, and reward-earn records (synthetic payouts) CRUD
non_simulatable_features: Live real-time market data feeds, true order-book depth, and price formation from external liquidity venues
Actual blockchain broadcasting, consensus finality, reorgs, mempool dynamics, and real network fees/confirmation times
Real custody operations and on-chain fund availability constraints tied to actual wallets/UTXOs/nonce management
Real compliance checks (sanctions/PEP screening, fraud scoring) that depend on third-party data/services
True bank/card processing (ACH/wire/card authorization, chargebacks, settlement) and external banking rails
Production-grade security infrastructure (device fingerprinting, anomaly detection, real 2FA delivery via SMS/auth apps)
Regulatory reporting integrations that require real jurisdictional rules, filings, and external systems
Genuine educational content quality/value beyond short synthetic module metadata (the instructional material itself)
